item.title: Matt add a quote by Neal Stephenson
item.description: "Until a man is twenty-five, he still thinks, every so often, that under the right circumstances he could be the baddest motherfucker in the world. If I moved to a martial-arts monastery in China and studied real hard for ten years. If my family was wiped out by Colombian drug dealers and I swore myself to revenge. If I got a fatal disease, had one year to live, and devoted it to wiping out street crime. If I just dropped out and devoted my life to being bad." -- Neal Stephenson

item.title: Matt add a quote by J. G. Ballard
item.description: "It was an excess of fantasy that killed the old United States, the whole Mickey Mouse and Marilyn thing, the most brilliant technologies devoted to trivia like instant cameras and space spectaculars that should have stayed in the pages of Science Fiction . . . some of the last Presidents of the U.S.A. seemed to have been recruited straight from Disneyland." -- J. G. Ballard

item.title: Matt add a quote by Don DeLillo
item.description: "California deserves whatever it gets. Californians invented the concept of life-style. This alone warrants their doom." -- Don DeLillo

item.title: Matt add a quote by Hunter S. Thompson
item.description: "When the going gets weird, the weird turn professional." -- Hunter S. Thompson

item.title: Matt add a quote by Nelson Algren
item.description: "... Chicago divided your heart. Leaving you loving the joint for keeps. Yet knowing it never can love you." -- Nelson Algren

item.title: Matt add a quote by Joseph Heller
item.description: "He was going to live forever, or die in the attempt." -- Joseph Heller

item.title: Matt add a quote by David Foster Wallace
item.description: "The truth will set you free. But not until it is finished with you." -- David Foster Wallace

item.title: Matt add a quote by Kurt Vonnegut
item.description: "Those who believe in telekinetics, raise my hand." -- Kurt Vonnegut

item.title: Matt add a quote by Karl Marlantes
item.description: "Emotion constricted Hawke’s throat. He suddenly understood why the victims of concentration camps had walked quietly to the gas chambers. In the face of horror and insanity, it was the one human thing to do. Not the noble thing, not the heroic thing—the human thing. To live succumbing to the insanity, was the ultimate loss of pride." -- Karl Marlantes
